reviewText:
I've owned DFUW since before it was on Steam.  I don't play through Steam so my playtime is not represented correctly.  I have over 1000 hours pretty easily.

Best current mmo because they put 6 things together that no other mmo does.  Many games can claim to do a couple of these things better, but no other game is the complete package.

FPS style combat with friendly fire, Not tab target, you actually have to aim and lead targets.
Territory control with player built cities and siege warfare.
Full loot PvP.  Take everything from your enemy, whether it's weapons, armor, treasure or even a warship.
Seamless world, no instances.
Classless characters, you don't have to be just a healer or tank, do everything you want to do or specialize as you please.
Nonlinear character progression with no levels, do whatever you want to do to build up your character and never be left out because you aren't high enough level to venture into any zone or dungeon.
Darkfall also has arguably the best ship combat in an mmo.  Ships come in all sizes, from rafts and fishing vessels to man-o-wars that are 10x the size of a house and require dozens of people to operate optimally.

Darkfall is made by a small indie company so the interface and controls can take a little getting used to, but once you've reconfigured your binds and settled in, it's not much different from any other 1st/3rd person action game.  It's based on territory control and clan warfare so don't plan on playing solo for too long.  There are plenty of clans in the game that are always looking for new members, it's easy to join up and start warring with other clans right away.

Before I start this, I should note that I don't feel I have played long enough to make a full review, I just know in advance that I wont have time to play the rest of the free week. So take these as more of a set of notes, than any type of in depth review.



Darkfall Unholy Wars is a decent mmo, it really is but I have got to say its really only worthwhile if you are part of a niche hardcore pvp mmo audience. If pvp and crafting are not your focus in an mmo, this is probably not the mmo for you.

Character creation is decent/ average, you get to chose your race, skin tone, facial features, ect. But once you get in game you start to notice the differences almost immediately. The game is action based so you will have to aim your attacks and spells in first person, or third person if you are a melee class. The actual combat reminds me a bit of the combat in Elder Scrolls Online, but alot less polished feeling.

The User Interface I have got to say is one of the worst I have ever seen though. Even after I learned where everything was in it, actually using the UI just felt terrible. I have a certain respect for anyone who plays the game regularly without customizing it in some usable way. The game uses a classless skill based system, and you will probably spend a lot of your time grinding crafting materials and skill experience/ points. I believe there is a way to do this AFK, though aside from just setting your character to mine, chop, fish or what have you, and walking away (or alt tabbing) I don't know of any way to do this.

As for the appearance of the game, I have got to say graphics wise its nothing special. Its got a non cartoony High fantasy style. The Graphics themselves look to be from anywhere between 2005 - 2008 if I where to guesstimate.

It does not look bad but I would not say its good looking either, just average I guess. I dont know what else to say about the game besides I reccomend any new players to join a clan. Do not try to figure the game out solo, it will be so much harder, and take so much longer if you dont have help. Dont be afraid to ask for help in game, like what something is or what a stat does, ect. Also watch out for trolls.

Overall I have got to say I recommend this game to hard core pvp and sandbox mmo fans. There is a good deal of fun to be had if you end up liking the game. IT does have its issues, and I do not know how the populations is during normal game hours (I am playing during the free week so there are a ton more players atm). I wish you all luck!

This review is for people who are familiar with Eve Online and I will use it draw comparisons.  I will first list the features that both games have, which is the primary reason why I like these games.

Player controlled cities/holdings
Player controlled buildings
Player built ships
Full crafting system where just about everything in game is built by players.
Full market system with buy/sell orders.
PVP is mandatory, if you go out to kill some mobs you always have to be watching your back.
You will lose your loot if killed by a player to that player.
Personally I played Eve Online for about a year and half, and I only had one single problem with.  The downtime is excruciating most of the time.  10% of Eve Online is great fun, because very interesting things can happen in a player controlled world like that, however the other 90% can be extremely boring.  Darkfall addresses this problem quite well.

Darkfall has many systems that encourage players to leave relative safety of clan holdings.  This encourages players to leave there cities to accomplish many tasks.  There are city levies, which take time to be emptied and you must protect yourself or take the risk of gaining massive loot.  Treasure maps can be found which will give you some basic direction of where to find actual good loot drops to dig out of the ground.  Just recently while treasure hunting I was forced to walk through enemy territory to find the loot.  These are just a couple of ways that PVP is encouraged and exploration as well.  The map is big enough to provide relative enough safety and you can always hide behind a rock and hope they don't see you.

The sieges and boat system adds to the complexity of the game.  Of course this game is for hardcore players, most people are not going to like it.  Before finding Darkfall I was playing Rust and trying to get into DayZ.  I was interested in the idea of fearing for my life every time I go out.  Darkfall does this in ways I wasn't expecting.

The progression system makes the game

Warnings
Don't leave relative safety with any items you are not willing to lose.  Bank your loot often.
You must find a group and have a mic, use teamspeak and find a decent clan, most will accept noobs.  Plenty of terrible clans out there, but plenty of good ones too.  Finding a good clan makes or breaks this game, it's an MMO not a single player adventure.  Join one as soon as possible, they can help you learn much more quickly.  If you join Darkfall planning to play solo, while possible, it is not going to be fun in the end.  I play solo half the time until I'm needed for a fight or raiding party, however I'm generally always in teamspeak while playing unless I'm simply harvesting resources or crafting.
There is a lot of grinding, if that's not for you then don't subscribe.
You cannot repair armor or weapons, once it is destroyed by durability it is gone forever.  However this keeps the market stable and makes it so resources are always in demand, Darkfall has one the most lucrative and stable markets of any MMO including Eve Online because of this.
Crafting can be very tedious, but partly what I like about this game is harvesting resources and crafting is very easy to do while watching Netflix or otherwise doing other things online.
This is not some tab based skill cooldown game like WOW, it is live action and fast paced meaning FPS skill is more important than your actual build in some ways.
The interface is very old school and takes a lot of getting used to, however I grew to actually like it.
Graphics are not amazing nor are they terrible.
Tips
Make plenty of bags and organize your loot in your bank.  It's the games way of managing the massive amount of items you will find.
Save all your loot you get.  It's almost all useful in someway or can be sold on the market.  Salvage items you don't need.
Set out to finish your feats, it's the easiest way to gain prowess.
Gather resources on your downtime while watching Netflix or surfing the net.  Every little thing you do in this game gives you prowess which can be spent on any skill or stat.

reviewText: I hesitate to write a review so early in the piece, but I was very pleasantly surprised by my first session of Darkfall.  I knew what I was getting into because I played Mortal Online for about a year in about 2010, when the game was very buggy and had broken features.  I'm told MO has improved since.  These independent, shoestring budget operations are works in progress, but I encountered no glitches in Darkfall.  The interfaces all worked, the crafting made sense, and the PvE combat was as it should be: I died to mobs at first but then started to get the hang of things.  The environment looks empty, but that's the nature of these games.  People try to stay hidden out of safe zones unless they are looking for action or have nothing to lose.  I played during the Aussie day on the US server, and there were plenty of players around in the town, and a couple in the wild to.  One, who came upon me trying my hand on Goblins and who I basically fled from until I realised he wasn't going to pinch my meagre noob stash, ended up inviting me to his guild.\n\nThese styles of game are superb, fantastically immersive, and great fun whether you like to play a killer, an empire builder, or a running away artisan like myself.  I hope you decide to buy this game and graduate from themeparks into a world where you can truly leave your mark.

I'd give DFUW a rating of 8/10 but that being said this is my favorite game and there just isn't any better for full loot PvP/sandbox gaming.

I've had an active sub for 2 months. I was inactive for the first 2 weeks due to computer issues. I've made it to 125k prowess and I feel strong. Its enough to max 3 weapon skills, my boosters in strength and dex, my base stats to 100str, 100dex, 70int, 80wis, 2 ults, a handful of leveled spells, and 2 crafting masteries. I'd say the key to get to where I am is to find at least one other solid player that you can farm with alot. Having a farming friend makes the spawns trigger faster, makes kills faster, and gives you a buddy to help you to your feet when you get knocked to the ground. Each of you pick a few different crafting skills to train (as this gives you self made gear whenever you want it, and also prowess) and trade each other for the things you need. Either way, the key is to have at least one trustworthy buddy to go farm with. Its also a decent way to make friends and get invited into a clan.

Running into other players:
I typically run into 3-12 instances of seeing other players doing ♥♥♥♥ per day I play. Requisitions, farming mobs, sea scrapping, etc (although its not uncommon for me to spot you, then slink off sneaky-like and get away) ((makes me wonder how many times I had unseen eyes looking me over)) keep in mind my playtime ranges from 3-10 hours per day depending on work and other IRL factors.

reviewText:
Darkfall Unholy Wars review from a new player (started playing beginning of Feb 2014):

The main purpose of this review is to help you determine whether or not darkfall is for you, as I understand this game is not for everyone. Will YOU enjoy it? Read below and find out!

First of all, you need to understand Darkfall is a pure HARDCORE PVP game.
Apart from the starting/safe zones. you can attack anyone / anytime / anywhere (even party members and guildies!)
When you kill a player, you can loot anything that is currently on him (BUT items deposited in banks are safe).

That being said, in order to enjoy this game you need to:
1. Love PVP in its most cruel & hardcore form
2. Love world PVP as there are no BG's or arenas.
3. Join a guild (a clan) as roaming alone will get you nowhere (at first). Only by joining a clan you will understand the true purpose of the game.
4. Be ready to do a bit of grinding in order to level (acquire prowess) - being in a clan will help you become PVP ready much faster as guildies can help you with feats/lend you fishing trawlers (to powerlevel)/and provide you with tips and better understand of the game.
5. Rebind you keys to your liking.
6. Get over the odd interface.

IF your focus is PVE or questing or if you dislike PVP or are a very casual player or a loner by all mean stay away from this game!

Do I personally enjoy the game? Here's my experience:
I started playing this game about a month ago. The first time I logged on I was a bit turned off by the controls and the interface. With proper keybinding I was able to get over this. I then started doing a bit of reading in order to understand better the game and learned how to build my caracther (a skirmisher). I then started gathering prowess by all possible means (mobs grinding & skinning, gathering, crafting, explorations, prowess monolith, feats, etc...)
At this point I was getting more confortable with the game and felt it was time for me to start PVPing. I tried roaming around the world by myself but without success. Either i'd meet over geared player and would get crushed or I would simply not find anyone to fight...
Until I joined a clan (Zerg), got summoned to my clan keep, hoped on Teamspeak... and started raiding other clan keeps!
I can now say that I'm truly having a blast playing Darkfall, as nothing beats the feeling of running around with a dozen guidlies / traveling by boats in order to lay an attack on other clans.
I still have a lot to discover & understand but so far as a PVPer by heart I'm really enjoying this game.

SUMMARY:
This game is great IF you enjoy HARCORE WOLD PVP and if you are ready to take the time to understand the game, join a clan and farm/grind a bit in order to become pvp ready (you'lll need around 15k-30k prowess, which is easily attainable within a week or two with proper clan support - lots of clans are currently recruiting new players - ie: Zerg clan). Trawling (fishing on a boat is for example a very fast way to gain prowess, but beware of pirates!).

I hope you will find this review helpefull, hope to see you in game,
Bull Rott

reviewText: A huge world with a full loot mechanic and the ability to kill anyone and anything at any time outside of safe zones. Its basicly a giant sandbox meaning you can just start doing whatever you feel like from the start. You can start harvesting reasources or killing mobs. It takes about a week or so before you are ready to pvp. You have a few ways of fighting in this game as well, you can be a warrior that uses melee or a brawler that uses speed, agility and lighter armor than a warrior but who also uses daggers. Or an archer, elementalist or a primalist. Since they removed classes in this game you now have the ability to mix and mash any of these and more that you like so the one character restriction limit they enforce upon you doesn't really matter because of this. If your looking for a giant sandboxy hardcore themed mmo with full loot and have some friends to join you then this game is probably worth a shot with the $15 price tag. If you are someone who gets really attached to items or plans on going solo then your chances of enjoying this game are a bit lower since this game is heavily group oriented. This doesn't mean you can't play alone though it will just take longer to earn prowess, upgrade your character and you have the risk of being overwhelmed by groups of players. reviewText: Okay I will start of by saying this is EASILY one of the best MMORPGs I have ever played... I've played everything from Runescape, World of Warcraft, Ultima Online, Guild Wars 1 & 2; you get the point.  With that being said I'd have to say my top 3 were Runescape, World of Warcraft, and Ultima Online as my number one favorite.  If you have ever played Ultima Online or Runescape you will feel the nostalgia almost immediately.  This is definitely a 3d version of these games with amazing graphics and much more.  I see a lot of the negative reviews about this game and it is kind of disappointing because a lot of them didn't really even give the game a chance... some only having half an hour on account.. I see a lot of complaints about the user interface etc.  But isn't a game more about gameplay? I mean 2 of my all time favorite games had very sh*tty graphics...  I won't deny the fact that the user interface could be a LITTLE better and the game still has few flaws but I mean every game is going to have issues, it doesn't matter what it is.  If you thoroughly enjoy PvP in games and hell even some good PvE this is definitely the game for you...  Some of the mechanics in this game are some that I have never seen before such as player owned cities, hamlets, villages, sea towers, housing and so on..  I've never played a game where you could fight other boats, destroy them, and then take the fight to the water to fight to the death.  This is definitely one of the most exhilerating PvP games I've ever played and I get an adrenaline rush from time to time.. If you try the game you'd understand.  This is a full-loot game where you lose all of your items when you die but don't let that scare you because there are safe zones, banks, and so on.  I won't deny the fact that this game is a little tricky to get used to but if you give the game a chance and actually try to learn it with an honest effort, I can promise that anyone willing to do that would not regret it.  My best advice to anyone reading this review would be to give the game a shot and find some players willing to help in game because there are plenty of them willing to help newbs learn the ropes, myself included.  I'll end this review by saying don't let the full-loot scare you away because there are ways around it and you can farm in safe zones in order to build yourself a nice little bank before you're ready to get into the actual game.  Give'r a whirl, take it from someone who actually has a lot of hours on the game :) hope to see some more newbs!

reviewText:
This Review is of Darkfall:UW's current state.

Darkfall had it charms since it originally launched however it has long suffered from design and technical flaws. However alot of work and thought has been put into making it what it is today and the biggest issues have largly been resolved. The economy patch as well as other improvments have made loot tables far more interesting and valuable. Changes to how higher end materials are aquired give players several different methods and path to aquiring them. The combat system is robust and highly customizable. The siege system is better than it has ever been. The removal of diminishing returns on prowess aquisition makes advancing your character much less grindy. Overall I feel darkfall is at the point where it is realizing its original vision. There are several improvments to gUI beign worked on as well as some other features like an alignment system which are on the horizon. There is talk of more sandbox type features being added in the future. If there is one thing this game is suffering from it is reputation and too few players. I think this game has a real shot at regaining momentum as there is no other game that is truly comparable to darkfall. It has built an excellent foundation to build on.

Some of the negative reviews on steam are well deserved as this game has had some rough patches, however being an MMO and its continued development this has changed. I am very glad to have rediscovered this game, after being away since the launch of DF:UW I can say it is a much much more enjoyable experience.

User interface:  it's HORRIBLE, tiny icons requiring double clicks, inventory on giant screen-wrapping scroll bars, no feedback on anything, no lists (most things are 5-6 double-clicks deep in invisible menus). reviewText:
This game is a 20% safe area game, with the other 80% all PvP.

In the game, you can choose to be an Elementalist(Mage), Warrior(Melee), Skirmisher(Ranger), or Primalist(Healer). You also have the choice to train your skills in all of them and switch between what you want to be. But it takes time to swap between classes, so you can only be one at a time, and not switch up in combat.

For everything you do in this game, you gain something equal to experience, but it's called Prowess.
Prowess is used as a form of currency and is used to spend on your skills. So spend wisely.
Players do not have a combat level, or skill total level, they have a prowess level. The amount of prowess a player has, can determine on how strong they are. But just remember, they might of spent it all on gathering skills and not their combat skills, so you might have a chance. Thats the exciting part. A player with 15k prowess could kill a player with 100k prowess. depending on what each player spends their prowess on. :)

The game is focused around clans, and taking over cities and villages, with a huge PvP based world. Everything outside of the safe zone is all for all. Anyone you see in the wilderness, you can attack. But be careful, you might annoy a clan, and they might track you down with spies.

The wilderness in this game has five levels of wilderness plus the safe zone areas. As soon as you step out of the safe zone, you have 30 seconds before your character is unsafe. What you have on you, you will lose if you die. Except your three basic wepons; your bow, staff and sword. The lowest of all wepons that every player in the game has.
The deeper the wilderness, the harder the NPC monsters will be, and the more loot they will drop. This also goes for trees, rocks, and other gathering noads.

You've got the freedom to do what you wish in the game.
You can gather items to get your crafting skills up, Eg; mine iron ore and smelt that into Iron Ignots, to make armour or wepons, or just to sell to other players to gain Gold Coins.
Or you could choose to PvE, and kill NPC monsters to loot items and skin them with a skinning tool to get leather(to craft) and other items.
Or you could go out and PvP for money, or work together in a clan to keep your cities under protection and fight for them.

Other features on this game include player mounts, player boats, ships and also player houses.
